title: Human insula neurons respond to simple sounds during passive listening
journal: nature (e.g. chewing), the anterior insula is hyperactivated and 48
abstract: The insula is critical for integrating sensory information from the body with that arising from the environment. Although previous studies suggest that posterior insula is sensitive to sounds, auditory response properties of insula neurons have not previously been reported. Here, we provide the first report of a population of human single neuron data from the insula and provide comparative data from the primary auditory cortex, recorded intracranially from human participants during passive listening. In each condition, more than 330 single neurons were recorded in 11 participants. Almost a third of neurons in posterior insula and a smaller subset in anterior insula responded to simple tones and clicks. Responsive neurons were distributed throughout posterior and anterior insula and showed preferred frequency tuning. Onset latencies in the insula were similar to those in the primary auditory cortex but response durations were significantly shorter. Overall, these data highlight that insula neurons respond to auditory stimuli even in non-behaviorally relevant contexts and suggest an important contribution of audition to the postulated integrative functions of insular cortex.

Abstract 13 
The insula is critical for integrating sensory information from the body with that arising 14 
from the environment. Although previous studies suggest that posterior insula is 15 
sensitive to sounds, auditory response properties of insula neurons have not previously 16 
been reported. Here, we provide the first report of a population of human single neuron 17 
data from the insula and provide comparative data from the primary auditory cortex, 18 
recorded intracranially from human participants during passive listening. In each 19 
condition, more than 330 single neurons were recorded in 11 participants. Almost a third 20 
of neurons in posterior insula and a smaller subset in anterior insula responded to 21 
simple tones and clicks. Responsive neurons were distributed throughout posterior and 22 
anterior insula and showed preferred frequency tuning. Onset latencies in the insula 23 
were similar to those in the primary auditory cortex but response durations were 24 
significantly shorter. Overall, these data highlight that insula neurons respond to 25 
auditory stimuli even in non-behaviorally relevant contexts and suggest an important 26 
contribution of audition to the postulated integrative functions of insular cortex. 27 
 28 
Introduction 29 
The insula, buried within the lateral fissure, is a key brain region involved in processing 30 
of interoceptive signals [1-5] which includes sensations not only from within the interior 31 
or viscera of body (e.g. cardiac, respiration, hunger) but also those arising from the skin 32 
(e.g. pain, temperature  and affective touch; [1, 6] for a review, see [7]). Theoretical 33 
models of insula function suggest that these interceptive sensations form the basis for 34 
subjective feelings [8] and sense of bodily self [9]. By contrast, empirical evidence for 35 
the role of insula in processing of exteroceptive signals, such as sounds that are 36 . external to the body and not associated with interoceptive signals, remains scant, 37 
although there is some limited evidence implicating the insula in auditory processing. 38 
Case reports have shown that damage to the insula region can cause alterations in 39 
auditory perception [10-13], even without apparent damage to auditory cortex. 40 
Additionally, studies in animals [14-18], human neuroimaging using functional magnetic 41 
resonance imaging (fMRI) [19-22] and electrophysiology [23-29], suggest that activity 42 
within the insula may be modulated by sound, particularly when it is emotionally 43 
arousing (e.g. music) or behaviorally relevant (e.g. detection of an odd tone), while 44 
recent intracranial local field potential data highlight that posterior insula represents 45 
phonological features during both speech production and perception [30]. In 46 
misophonia, a condition characterized as an intense emotional reaction to sounds of a 47 
particular nature (e.g. chewing), the anterior insula is hyperactivated and 48 
hyperconnected when listening to trigger sounds [31]. This finding has been interpreted 49 
within the context of social cognition and interoceptive awareness [32, 33]. The insula 50 
has also been implicated in auditory hallucinations [34], and intracranial stimulation of 51 
this region can produce auditory sensations [35-37], although not always [38]. However, 52 
electrophysiological and imaging data have almost always been obtained in behaviorally 53 
salient contexts, such as music or speech, while lesion studies may not always be 54 
specifically localized to insula exclusively, and there are currently no reports of single 55 
neuron responses recorded in the human insula. 56 
Prior studies also do not address whether there is any tuning to basic acoustic sound 57 
attributes in the insula [39]. For example, neurons in primary auditory cortex are tuned 58 
to specific spectral and temporal features of acoustic stimuli [40-42]. Can activity of 59 
individual neurons in the insula also be modulated according to these fundamental 60 
acoustic properties even when stimuli are not behaviorally relevant? If so, what are the 61 
latencies and tuning properties of these neurons, and where are these located? 62 
We addressed this gap in knowledge by recording extracellular single neuron activity 63 
from the insula in eleven humans and comparing these recordings to those obtained 64 
from the adjacent posteromedial portion of Heschlâ€™s gyrus (HGPM), corresponding to 65 
primary auditory cortex [43]. Data were collected while participants passively listened to 66 
auditory stimuli consisting of short click trains and pure tones of various frequencies. 67 
This allowed us to determine (1) the extent of insula neurons that are responsive to 68 
auditory stimulation; (2) whether these neurons showed frequency tuning; (3) the spatial 69 
distribution of responsive neurons across posterior and anterior insula (InsP and InsA, 70 
respectively); and (4) the latencies, magnitudes, and durations of these responses 71 
compared to HGPM. Knowledge about the neuronal properties of this brain area in 72 
response in audition is important for understanding how the human brain processes 73 
sounds. This knowledge has additional relevance to auditory hallucinations and 74 
disorders such as tinnitus [44]. 75

Results  78 
Electrodes were implanted for clinical purposes of monitoring seizures and were 79 
localized based on pre- and post-operative neuroimaging (see Methods ). Single neuron 80 
responses to 40 ms 100 Hz click trains were recorded in a single 100-trial block. 81 
Responses to 300 ms tones were recorded in a separate block while participants were 82 
presented with pseudo-randomly ordered tones of varying frequency, from 0.25 kHz to 8 83 
kHz, separated by octave steps. Each tone was presented 50 times, resulting in 300 84 
trials total. Interstimulus intervals were 2 s in both experiments (see Methods  for full 85 
details of auditory stimulus presentation). 86 
Figure 1a displays the locations from which single neurons were successfully isolated, 87 
shown on a template reconstruction of the insula. The size of each marker indicates the 88 
number of neurons isolated at a particular location. For click stimuli, a total of 331 89 
neurons were isolated (57 HGPM neurons, 161 InsP neurons and 113 neurons in InsA). 90 
For pure tone stimuli, a total of 339 neurons were isolated (59 HGPM neurons, 156 InsP 91 
neurons and 124 InsA neurons). Figure 1b  shows spike waveforms, trial rasters, and 92 
kernel-smoothed spike density functions for exemplar neurons in HGPM, InsP and InsA 93 
(top to bottom panels, respectively) in response to click train stimuli. In these examples, 94 
HGPM shows a sharp onset response to the click train, while the InsP neuron responds 95 
consistently across trials with a slightly longer latency than HGPM, and the InsA neuron 96 
responds with an even longer latency, with visibly less consistent timing across trials. 97 
Figure 1c shows examples for three single neurons in these same brain locations in 98 
response to pure tone stimuli of different frequencies. The neurons in HGPM and InsP 99 
showed clear evidence of frequency tuning (to 8 kHz and 0.25 kHz, respectively). 100 
Tuning is less obvious in the InsA neuron, though significant suppression was observed 101 
in response to tonal stimuli of 2 kHz. 102 . Information such as response latencies can provide crucial information about the 103 
position of a region within the hierarchy of an information processing network [45-48]. 104 
Thus, to characterize the properties of neuronal responses to clicks across the 105 
population, we examined response magnitudes, latencies, and durations for modulated 106 
neurons in each region. For each neuron, significant modulation in response to auditory 107 
stimuli was determined by comparing the spike rates following the stimulus to the pre- 108 
stimulus baseline (see Methods). Trial-averaged raster plots for all significantly 109 
modulated neurons in each of the three regions are shown in Figure 2a. These are 110 
separated according to whether they increased or decreased their activity (indicated by 111 
the arrow directions). The overall proportion of modulation response types is then 112 
shown in Figure 2b . As is evident from both plots, the majority of modulated neurons 113 
increased their firing rates in response to click-train stimuli. Across all recorded neurons, 114

The magnitudes, latencies and durations of all positively modulated responses to click- 126 
train stimuli are shown in Figure 2c . The average magnitudes of responses following 127 
stimulus presentation (0 to 350 ms post-stimulus onset) in InsP and InsA were 128 
significantly smaller than HGPM ( p = 0.00170 and p = 0.00360, respectively), with no 129 
significant difference between InsP and InsA ( p = 0.424). Positively modulated InsP 130 
neurons exhibited similar latencies to HGPM neurons ( p = 0.361), with median latencies 131 
of 44.0 ms (interquartile range [IQR] = 48.8) and 48.5ms (IQR = 45.5), respectively 132 
(middle panel of 2C), which is suggestive of parallel hierarchical auditory processing 133 
between the two regions, while InsA latencies were notably slower (median = 67.0 ms, 134 
IQR = 57.2). InsP and InsA responses were significantly more transient than HGPM 135 
responses ( p = 0.008 and p  = 0.003, respectively; right panel in Figure 2c ), with InsP 136 
showing a median duration of 76 ms (IQR = 102.0) compared to a median of 153 ms 137 
(IQR = 146.5) in HGPM, highlighting that there were differences in response patterns 138 
between insula and HGPM neurons. InsA responses were even more transient (median 139 
= 41 ms, IQR = 58.5), though there was no significant difference overall between the 140 
response durations of InsP and InsA neurons ( p = 0.276). Modulated neurons were 141 
distributed throughout each subregion of insula, though there was an absence of 142 
modulation in the most ventral aspects of InsA (see Supplementary Figure 2).  143 
Figure 3 shows the response properties of the different regions for tones. Approximately 144 
one third of InsP were modulated by tones (30.8% total; 28.8% increasing, 1.92% 145 
decreasing). A higher proportion of neurons in HGPM were modulated by tones (94.9% 146 
total; 84.8% increasing, 10.2% decreasing), with a lower proportion in InsA modulated in 147 
response to tones compared to clicks (8.07% total; 5.65% increasing, 2.42% 148 
decreasing). As with click trains, there were significantly higher proportions of 149 
modulated neurons in HGPM compared to both InsP and InsA ( p < 0.0001 for both 150 
comparisons) and in InsP compared to InsA ( p < 0.0001). See Supplementary Figure 151 
3 for the spatial distribution of the proportion of tone-modulated neurons. 152 
We examined whether there were differences in frequency tuning for the different 153 
regions by determining the proportion of neurons showing a preference to each of the 154 
tone frequencies ( Figure 3b ). As the electrodes used in this study do not allow for 155 
determining the precise spatial location of wires relative to one another (they only show 156 
as a cluster of microwires on the magnetic resonance images [MRI] and do not clearly 157 
map to particular channels), along with the relative sparsity of sampling of certain areas 158 
of insula, we could not reliably obtain tonotopic maps for the individual electrode arrays. 159 
However, as with clicks, there was an absence of response modulation in ventral 160 
anterior insula. There was no clear preference for a particular tone frequency across 161 
neurons, although fewer neurons in HGPM modulated maximally to 4 kHz than other 162 
f
requencies. To determine whether there were differences in how precisely tuned insula 163 
neurons were, we assessed the bandwidth of responses to different tones (see 164 . Discussion 172 
Our results demonstrate that neurons in the human insula significantly modulate their 173 
activity in response to auditory stimuli that are passively presented, in the absence of 174 
any obvious behavioral or emotional salience. Responses in insula had similar latencies 175 
and bandwidths to HGPM, but were more transient. The highest proportion of these 176 
responses were in InsP, though a smaller minority of neurons in InsA were also 177 
modulated, albeit more weakly. Overall, these results suggest that processing of basic 178 
properties of acoustic stimuli contribute to the postulated role of the insula. 179 
The insula, particularly InsA, is known to be part of a salience network [49, 50] which 180 
detects and marks how behaviorally relevant the stimulus/events in the environment 181 
are. Depending on the degree of saliency, the insula mediates further processing by 182 
directing attention or allocating working memory by coordinating between different brain 183 
networks (e.g. activating a fronto-parietal network for attention and deactivating the 184 
â€˜mind wanderingâ€™ default mode network for a highly salient event). How does InsA 185 
receive sensory inputs for marking their saliency? Theoretical models of insula function 186 
[1, 50, 51] suggest that InsP receives sensory inputs which  are then re-represented in 187 
InsA. There is now ample evidence to support the idea that interoceptive signals from 188 
the body do indeed reach InsP [1]. Whether this is also the case for exteroceptive 189 
signals such as auditory, however, has historically been less certain. Our high spatial- 190 
temporal resolution single neuron data recorded from the insula highlights that â€“ like 191 
signals from the body â€“ auditory signals from the external environment are received in 192 
InsP . It should be noted that in the saliency model of insula function, stimuli need not be 193 
salient or behaviorally relevant to reach InsP , and they were not in the case of the 194 
presence study. The saliency of the stimuli is proposed to be marked in InsA. This 195 
model may then explain why in our data the proportion of modulated neurons is less in 196 
InsA compared to that in InsP when passively listening to sounds, as these sounds were 197 
not required to be salient. 198 
Evidence showing that insula activity is modulated even during passive listening may 199 
explain â€“ at least in part â€“ why lesions to the insula can cause altered auditory 200 
processing, such as in cases of acquired amusia, temporal processing deficits or 201 
hyperacusis after a stroke [52, 53]. The results of the current study are also consistent 202 
with neuroanatomical studies showing that the insula receives direct projections from 203 
auditory cortex [54, 55] and medial geniculate body [56], although as highlighted by 204 
Remedios et al. [14], anatomical results do not give insight into the nature of the 205 
involvement of the insula in auditory processing without corresponding physiological 206 
data, which we have provided here. 207 
These results may also explain why stimulation of insula can produce auditory 208 
perceptual experiences [35-37]. Contrasting with these other studies, Duong et al. [38] 209 . did not find auditory responses from stimulation of the insula, which the authors 210 
suggested was due to previous studies stimulating structures adjacent to rather than 211 
within the insula proper. In the current study, our electrode locations were confirmed to 212 
be in the insula based on individual participantsâ€™ MRIs, as well as plotted on a template 213 
using MNI coordinates. While it is plausible that some studies may have stimulated 214 
regions adjacent to the insula to produce auditory perceptual experiences, another 215 
possibility is that an absence of behavioral response may be due to the still relatively 216 
small fraction of neurons in this region being involved in auditory processing (about 1/3 217 
in the current study). Thus, if particular neurons were not stimulated by electrodes within 218 
the insula, then an auditory percept would likely not be produced. Further studies 219 
utilizing both stimulation mapping and auditory  presentation in the same neurons would 220 
be invaluable for elucidating the dynamics of these auditory-responsive insula neurons. 221 
Reports of the tuning properties of single neurons in HGPM are rare, with only a handful 222 
studies to date examining this [57-59]. In the first systematic study of individual neurons 223 
in human auditory cortex, the bandwidth measured in a similar manner to the current 224 
manuscript was at least 1 octave [58], consistent with what we found here. Contrastingly 225 
though, the bandwidth of neuronal responses to tones here was considerably larger 226 
than what was demonstrated previously when using an approach that estimates based 227 
on spectro-temporal receptive fields derived from random-chord stimuli [59]. It is 228 
therefore likely that basic tonal stimuli â€“ although widely used historically to study the 229 
function of the auditory system [60] â€“ do not reveal the full extent of the precision of 230 
stimulus encoding, and future studies should examine this with refined stimuli for both 231 
the HGPM and the insula. Moreover, while this study represents a rich and unique 232 
dataset, the spatial extent of electrode coverage was still somewhat limited, as 233 
determined solely by the clinical needs of the patients. This work lays the foundation for 234 
further, more comprehensive, studies aimed at understanding the full extent of auditory- 235 
related single neuron activation throughout the insula.   236 . Methods 237 
Participants 238 
Extracellular single neuron recordings were obtained from 11 adult neurosurgical 239 
patients, implanted with electrodes for the purposes of monitoring epileptiform activity 240 
prior to potential treatment. Research was conducted under approval of the University of 241 
Iowa Institutional Review Board and written informed consent was obtained from all 242 
participants prior to data collection. Recordings were made while subjects were reclined 243 
in a hospital bed, in a custom-designed dedicated electromagnetically-shielded facility 244 
within the University of Iowa Clinical Research Unit.  245 
 246 
Electrodes and recording system 247 
Stereo electroencephalography (sEEG) depth electrodes (Ad-Tech Medical, Oak Creek, 248 
WI) were placed in brain locations based solely on a clinical need to identify seizure foci 249 
[61]. For the purposes of recording single neurons, sEEG electrodes included here in 250 
the insula and HGPM were of a hybrid design [62]. These consisted of eight 39 Âµm 251 
diameter platinum-iridium high-impedance microwires that were insulated plus one 252 
uninsulated microwire. These microwires protruded from the end of the macro recording 253 
probe and were prepared with a cut length between 2 to 4 mm, depending on the 254 
distance of the most distal macro contact to the appropriate brain target. Each of these 255 
microwires was individually separated in a splay pattern in the operating room 256 
immediately prior to implantation. Electrode locations were confirmed based on post- 257 
operative MRI scans, preprocessed using Freesurfer [63] (see below for further details). 258 
All neurophysiological data were recorded using a Neuralynx Atlas System (Neuralynx, 259 
Bozeman, MT). High impedance recordings were first passed through a preamplifier 260 
located on top of the patientâ€™s head (ATLAS-HS-36-CHET-A9, Neuralynx, Bozeman, 261 
MT) prior to interfacing with the ATLAS acquisition system. These were subsequently 262 
recorded with a 32000 Hz sampling rate, filtered between 0.1 â€“ 8000 Hz and referenced 263 
online to the uninsulated microwire. 264 
 265 
Stimuli and procedure 266 
Experimental stimuli were trains of acoustic clicks (used previously in [64]) and pure 267 
tones (used previously in [65]). Clicks were digitally generated as rectangular pulses 268 
(0.2 ms duration) and were presented in trains of five at a rate of 100 Hz (train duration 269 
40 ms, 2 s inter-train interval). Tones were presented at six frequencies between 250 270 
and 8 kHz in 1-octave steps (300 ms duration, 5 ms riseâ€“fall time, 2 s interstimulus 271 
interval). The six tones were presented 50 times each in a random order. The stimuli 272 . were presented at a comfortable level, approximately 50-60 dB above hearing 273 
threshold. Stimuli were delivered to both ears via insert earphones (ER4B, Etymotic 274 
Research, Elk Grove Village, IL) that were integrated into custom-fit earmolds or foam 275 
ear tips (for two participants). In each participant, the intensity difference between click 276 
trains and pure tones was within 20 dB and varied depending on comfort. Inter-stimulus 277 
intervals were chosen randomly within a Gaussian distribution (mean interval 2 s; SD = 278 
10 ms) to reduce heterodyning in the recordings secondary to power line noise. 279 
Stimulus delivery was controlled by a TDT RP2.1 and RZ2 real-time processor (Tucker 280 
Davis Technologies, Alachua, FL). 281 
 282 
Imaging 283 
A T1-weighted structural MRI scan of the brain was conducted for each participant both 284 
before and after the implantation of electrodes. The images were captured using a 3T 285 
Siemens TIM Trio scanner and a 12-channel head coil. MPRAGE images had a spatial 286 
resolution of 0.78 Ã— 0.78 mm, a slice thickness of 1.0 mm, and utilized a repetition time 287 
(TR) of 2.53 s and an echo time (TE) of 3.52 ms. To locate the recording positions on 288 
the preoperative structural MRI scans, these images were aligned with post- 289 
implantation structural MRIs. This alignment was achieved using a 3D linear registration 290 
algorithm (Functional MRI of the Brain Linear Image Registration Tool; [66]) and custom- 291 
written MATLAB scripts (MathWorks, Natick, MA). Included microwire bundles were 292 
verified to be within gray matter for either the insula or HGPM. Electrode locations were 293 
co-registered for each participant to a template brain, in order to derive MNI coordinates 294 
for the purposes of visualization. Coordinates of microwire locations were then 295 
visualized on an fsaverage MRI template showing the insula and neighboring region of 296 
HGPM, using custom-written MATLAB scripts.  297 
 298 
Data processing and analysis 299 
Data from high impedance electrodes localized to the insula or HGPM were first 300 
extracted using Matlab and denoised with an implementation of the demodulated band 301 
transform [67]. These data were downsampled to 12 kHz and common average re- 302 
referenced to all high impedance contacts on the same assembly prior to spike sorting. 303 
Spike sorting was performed using an automated procedure with manual curation, 304 
utilizing an algorithm implementing high-order spectral decomposition to aid in pattern 305 
recognition and identify individual features [68]. Briefly, filters were estimated for 306 
potential candidate single neuron waveforms for each channel through a process 307 
related to blind deconvolution. Extracted features were clustered using a gaussian 308 
mixture model in Matlab (R2022a, Mathworks Inc) and spike times from these clustered 309 . features were used to plot separate candidate waveforms. Single neurons were then 310 
manually curated and defined based on classical waveform shapes, uniformity of 311 
waveforms across different spike times for each cluster, and interspike interval 312 
distributions that did not violate refractory periods (<1% of interspike intervals occurring 313 
within 1 ms). See Supplementary Figure 1  for summarized curation details. Putative 314 
single neuron spike times were then epoched around the stimuli for each trial (500 ms 315 
before stimulus onset to 1000 ms post-stimulus onset). Raster plots were created to 316 
show neuronal activity for each trial and spike density functions were estimated by 317 
convolving single neuron spike times with a gaussian kernel (1 ms resolution, generally 318 
5 ms standard deviation, though a standard deviation of 15 ms was used for display 319 
purposes in Figure 1 ). 320 
 321 
Statistical analysis 322 
Single neuron modulation to auditory stimuli was determined using a two-tailed paired t - 323 
test against baseline, wherein spike rates across trials between 0 to 350 ms post- 324 
stimulus were compared to baseline firing rates from a pre-stimulus window of the same 325 
duration (-400 to -50 ms). This was only considered for neurons that had a mean firing 326 
rate â‰¥1 Hz across the baseline and post-stimulus windows. The p -value alpha for this 327 
test was set at 0.05 for click stimuli and Benjamini-Hochberg false discovery rate (FDR) 328 
correction [69, 70]  was applied to tonal response p-values to account for multiple 329 
comparisons (based on the six different tone frequencies presented). Magnitudes for all 330 
responses were determined by averaging the z-scored firing rate across the post- 331 
stimulus window. The latency of significantly modulated neurons was then determined 332 
according to the first peak in the baseline z-scored spike density function from 10 ms to 333 
350 ms post-stimulus, wherein this peak was a minimum value of half of the maximum 334 
peak within this time window. For neurons that suppressed their activity in response to 335 
auditory stimuli, spike density functions were first inverted prior to finding the peak. For 336 
tone stimuli, the best frequency of each neuron was defined as the tone that elicited the 337 
maximum absolute value of the z-scored average, wherein this response was 338 
significant. Bandwidth in octaves was determined based on the full width at half 339 
maximum of this frequency, which was obtained after interpolation of both frequencies 340 
and magnitudes to create 10000 discrete sampling points. Where the lowest or highest 341 
frequencies were the maximum absolute value (i.e. showed the strongest modulation), 342 
these were taken as the low or high cutoff for this calculation, respectively. Response 343 
durations were determined based on the time after the first peak wherein the spike 344 
density function was reduced to 5% of the maximum peak value. Regional differences in 345 
response properties were examined using a linear mixed effects modeling approach. 346 
Output (response magnitude, latency or duration) was modeled using region of interest 347 .
